head.title: Social Security, as Seen at 19 and 65

hedline.hl1: Social Security, as Seen at 19 and 65

abstract.p: Stephen Distler letter explains that Social Security money could be invested throughout working person's life, to smooth ups and downs of stock market (S)

block.p: Paul Krugman (column, May 17) suggests that the market's current overvaluation makes this an inappropriate time to invest Social Security in stocks. Much as I agree with his valuation assessment, participant contributions to the proposed plan would be only 2 percentage points of the 12.4 percent payroll tax.

It's not that significant amounts must suddenly be invested at inflated market levels. Rather, this amount (presumably adjusted for inflation) would be invested yearly throughout a participant's 40-year working life, which would smooth the ups and downs of the market over time.
